ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

LAND FOR NON-POLLUTIVE FARMING IN PUNGGOL
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development what acreage of land has been successfully tendered out for non-pollutive farming activities in Punggol due to the phasing out of small pig farms; how much land is still available; and when these parcels of land will be tendered out.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, a total of some 22 hectares of land have been vacated by small pig farmers in Punggol. Of this, 9 hectares are earmarked for HDB's development. Out of the remaining 13 hectares of land, 3 hectares have been tendered out for non-pollutive farming on a three-year tenancy agreement. The rest of the land will be tendered out over the next six months.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, could the Minister of State for National Development indicate as to how the rest of the land will be tendered out for non-pollutive farming, taking into consideration that much land has already been acquired and is now lying idle?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, in my answer I touched on lands that were affected by the phasing out of small pig farmers in Punggol. The total land that is available in Punggol is much more than what is given in my answer. Our exercise on the use of these vacant land takes in land that were vacated prior to the phasing out of pig farming, and also land that were

Column: 236

used for non-pig farming activities. We have included these land in various exercises for tenders on short-term leases to non-pollutive farmers. As a whole, we have tendered out about 25 hectares of other land which are available for non-pollutive pig farming. Various types of farming are being encouraged for these land and they include vegetable and food crop cultivation, orchid and ornamental flower cultivation, aquarium fish breeding, dog breeding and dog training, and turf production.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: In that case, Sir, could the Hon. Minister of State indicate how his Ministry will expedite and probably increase the tenure of lease so as to encourage the optimal use of such lands?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the land are being tendered out on short-term leases, three year-leases. I would agree with the Member for Punggol that if we could, we should extend the lease to make it more attractive. However, the pace of development in Singapore is such that it is very difficult at this point of time to envisage longer leases. In fact, out of the land that has been vacated by the small pig farmers, 9 hectares have already been set aside for early development by HDB and only 3 hectares have been taken up by farmers. It would be very difficult at this point of time to give a commitment that there will be longer leases for such land as development of this land is expected to take place shortly. At the present point of time we can only envisage a three-year lease.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Supplementary question.

     Mr Speaker: Are you speaking on behalf of Punggol? The question raised is on Punggol.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: No. Supplementary question, please, Mr Speaker.

     Mr Speaker: All right.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I want to ask the Minister of State a question in regard to pieces of land that are about to be tendered out and have been tendered out,

Column: 237

and if I could stretch the question on Punggol to other parts of Singapore. These pieces of land were in the first place acquired from existing farmers. Existing farmers were driven out, Government acquired the land and then they were parcelled and then tendered out. Is that the correct position?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, some of the land which are presently being tendered out for use on short-term leases are indeed lands that were previously used for farming. But these were farms which had caused pollution, for example, pig farms, and they could not be allowed to continue because of the pollution problem. As such, the farmers had to give up farming on these land and the land were reverted to the State. Since there is no immediate use for these land in terms of other developments, my Ministry has decided that we should, in the interim, allow those who are interested to use these lands for non-pollutive farming.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Is the Minister of State saying that all the pieces of land that were acquired and subsequently parcelled out for tenders for farming again were all pollutive in nature and that was why they were acquired?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Sir, the lands that were acquired in Punggol were all lands which were used for pig farming before. There were also other lands which, as I have mentioned, were already vacant; they were not being used and these were acquired by the Government.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Perhaps the Minister of State does not understand the thrust of my question. My question is basically this. These pieces of land that have been tendered out and about to be tendered out, were they originally taken compulsorily from existing farmers? Is that the position? The farmers were already there; you take their land and then you tender out at a higher price. Is that the position?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have to repeat my answer. Not all the land were acquired from existing farmers. Some of the land were. As for those land which were already occupied by farmers,

Column: 238

these were the farmers who were practising pollutive farming, for instance, pig farming, and therefore the Government had to acquire these farmlands and put it to other uses which would not cause problems of pollution.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: One more question. In regard to Punggol, if I am not wrong, the Government has, in fact, already asked those pig farmers in Punggol to install expensive devices to make pig farming non-pollutive. Is that not the position? The farmers have put in as much as a million dollars in capital to install them. And he says that they are pollutive.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the question of pig farming has been debated in this House in 1984/1985. The decision to phase out pig farming in Punggol was taken in 1984.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Just answer the question. You say that they were pollutive.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Some of the pig farmers in Punggol have installed pollution treatment equipment. But these are necessary so long as they want to continue to farm, and those that have installed such expensive treatment equipment are still there at the present moment.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: But they were asked to leave, were they not?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: None of them has been asked as of now to leave now. They are still there, farming. They know that the prospect of pig farming in Singapore is limited and that in the future they will have to be phased out.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Question 2, Sir.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: May I ask the Minister that if that is the position ---?

     Mr Speaker: Question No. 2 has been asked.

SINGLE SESSION SCHOOLS
(Progress of implementation)


    4. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for Education what progress has been made so far in the implementation of single session schools for secondary education.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Speaker, Sir, in January 1986 a pilot project was initiated in 20 schools to study in detail how the Single Session System could benefit the pupils and the operational difficulties that might be encountered. The results of the pilot project were reported in the Schools Council Meeting on 10 January this year. It is clear that the single session system will result in major benefits for schools, such as more time and opportunity for remedial work, ECA and other things. The Ministry has therefore decided to implement the single session in all schools beginning with the secondary schools. The implementation of the single session system will be done in phases.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Does the Minister of State not think that it is more important to have small classes first rather than to have single session schools with big classes? What is the position?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Speaker, Sir, a number of things were raised in discussions with principals and parents at the recent forums conducted by the Minister for Education. I think the Member for Potong Pasir should wait until the Minister

Column: 241

has the opportunity to tell the House the response of the Ministry to the various points, including class sizes.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, I think this question of smaller classes in our schools today is a genuine pressing problem. I am not bringing up this question just for the sake of bringing it up. It is a pressing problem and I brought this matter up more than once in this House. But nothing concrete has been done. Perhaps the Minister could give some kind of a commitment, whether or not some concret steps have been taken to reduce the number of pupils, say, to 30 for a start.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon:I suggest that he wait until Thursday or Friday when the Minister for Education will make his statement on these matters.

MURDER AND ROBBERY
(Figures involving foreigners)


    6. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what was the number of murders and firearm robberies committed from January 1986 up to the latest available date and how many of them were committed by foreigners; and (b) what measures are being taken to ensure that criminals from foreign countries will not enter Singapore.

Column: 242



     The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, the number of murders committed during the period January 1986 to 4th March 1987 was 73. 40 cases were solved to date, and of these, 12 cases were committed by foreigners.

    The number of firearm robberies reported during the period January 1986 to 3rd March 1987 was 19. Of these, 4 cases have been solved and only 1 case was committed by foreigners.

    The various enforcement agencies like the Police and the Central Narcotics Bureau work very closely with each other and the Immigration Department to identify and prevent foreign criminals from entering Singapore. Identities of notorious criminals are established through investigations or through the exchange of information with enforcement agencies of other countries. Such criminals are barred from entering Singapore. In addition, foreigners convicted of serious criminal offences in Singapore are repatriated and prohibited from re-entry after their release from prison. Our tough laws and effective Police enforcement also act as deterrents.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Sir, how many of these foreign criminals mentioned by the Minister of State are also work permit holders?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, out of the 19 foreigners who were involved in murder cases in 1986, 9 of them were on work permits.

NEIGHBOURHOOD POLICE POST IN JALAN KAYU


    7. Mr Heng Chiang Meng asked the Minister for Home Affairs when a neighbourhood police post or posts will be provided in Jalan Kayu Constituency.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, the two neighbourhood police posts in Jalan Kayu Constituency are scheduled for 1989. However, the Police will try to have them ready by 1988.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Jalan Kayu): Supplementary questions, Sir. (1) How

Column: 243

many constituencies already have neighbourhood police posts? (2) Are there already any constituencies with more than one neighbourhood police post? (3) If so, how many? (4) Since the original schedule for building NPPs was drawn up, has the original order of establishment been changed? (5) On what basis was this original schedule drawn up?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the neighbourhood police post scheme was designed to achieve a target of 91 posts throughout all the constituencies in Singapore. I believe, as of now, more than 50 have been implemented.

    The Member wants to know how many constituencies have more than one neighbourhood police post. As at present, there are two constituencies which have more than one neighbourhood police post. But the final plan envisages 12 constituencies to have more than one neighbourhood police post. Presently, the two constituencies which have more than one neighbourhoold police post are Thomson and Serangoon Garden Constituencies.

    Sir, the Member's next question is whether the schedule for implementation of neighbourhood police posts has been changed. The original schedule which was drawn up in 1983 has over the years been reviewed to meet with the changes in development which have taken place in between. For instance, the emphasis on the development of certain new towns which were not formulated prior to 1983.

    The Member wants to know the basis for this order of implementation. In formulating the neighbourhood police post scheme, the Police had to take into consideration several factors. This includes the rate and the locality of public housing developments. Priority has to be given to constituencies which have established major public housing estates. For constituencies which have new town development, the construction of NPPs will be incorporated into the new town as it is being built. This is because the early establishment of NPPs in a new town will help to foster a closer relationship between the Police and the residents. And it is also from Police experience that during the early days of a new town's development, it

Column: 244

is vital to enhance the sense of security among the new residents.

    The other factor which has to be considered is whether constituencies without intensive public housing estates should take precedence in the schedule of implementation. Generally, the Police felt that these constituencies without the high density public housing development should be accorded lower priority. This is because private residential estates, unlike the high-rise public housing estates, can be adequately covered by bicycle and divisional police car patrols.

    Lastly but not least, the Police have also to consider the availability of trained manpower in order to staff the neighbourhood police posts. Each neighbourhood police post requires a minimum of about 20 trained officers. And these are not just officers who are trained in the normal police work but officers who have received extra training by way of better inter-personal relationships to be able to deal with the public who come to the NPPs. Given the manpower constraint within the Police Force, we can only manage to establish about 14-15 neighbourhood police posts per year and the implementation will therefore have to be phased out accordingly.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, given the manpower constraint, if certain new things come up, eg, during the Committee of Supply, will the Minister of State reconsider the order of the queue? Because we do understand that you cannot set up all the NPPs at once but I am just talking about the order of the queue.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have said earlier on, the Police are always reviewing the schedule of implementation for the NPPs and will take into consideration any new factor which the Member for Jalan Kayu is able to bring up.

(Upgrading of facilities)


    8. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Acting Minister for Health whether his Ministry has any plans to upgrade the facilities of Ang Mo Kio Polyclinic.

Column: 245

It is the Ministry's policy to regularly upgrade its facilities to meet the needs of the general public. As part of the upgrading of Ang Mo Kio Polyclinic, a computerized patient management system is being planned and will be installed by 1988 at the clinic. New equipment will also be acquired as and when necessary to meet the needs of the patients.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Sir, as the Polyclinic is being overused, what steps are being taken to cut down the waiting time at the Polyclinic?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, part of the problem with the peak load is that many of the patients tend to arrive at the Polyclinic in the early hours of the morning between 8 and
9.30 am. What happens is that patients on their way to the market will drop in at the Polyclinic or bring along with them their children who are sick. This adds up to a tremendous peak load, which is very hard to overcome. What the Polyclinic staff do is to explain to the patients that they should try to come at all times of the day rather than to come all at the same time. However, recognizing that there is a problem with the queuing time, my Ministry is planning to send another doctor to the Ang Mo Kio Polyclinic later this year.

NOISE POLLUTION IN HDB ESTATES


    9. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for National Development whether noise pollution is a serious problem in Housing and Development Board Estates and whether stricter rules will be introduced to control noise pollution.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, in high-rise community living, it must be appreciated that a certain amount of noise is inevitable. In the case of HDB estates, the sources of noise are major roads and expressways, nearby construction sites, commercial premises, markets and hawker centres, and functions carried out in the void decks. Noise pollution from these sources can generally be controlled

Column: 246

through various planning and management measures. However, excessive noise generated by residents themselves is harder to eliminate.

    The HDB will work closely with grassroots organizations such as RCs to advise and counsel residents against generating excessive noise. But residents themselves must be more considerate and cooperative with their neighbours. They must take simple measures to make high-rise living more pleasant such as restraining their dogs from barking and keeping the volume of their TV or radio sets low. The HDB will be glad to receive suggestions from residents and grassroots organizations on what kind of stricter rules can be formulated, how these can be enforced with minimum cost to themselves and the type of punitive measures that can be introduced.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Sir, with regard to noise disturbance from neighbours in the HDB estates, what further action is being taken by the HDB in those cases where the recalcitrant residents refuse to cooperate and take heed of friendly advice or warning letters from the HDB?

     Mr Dhanabalan:Sir, the present procedure is that when the HDB receives a complaint, they do go to the house complained against and they counsel the owner. They speak to him, and this is done many times. As far as I am aware, nobody has yet been evicted from his flat for making noise that bothers his neighbours. But as I said, this is a difficult problem because some of the problems are in blocks comprising purchased flats, and eviction, of course, is not a simple process. That is why I said that this is a community problem and we will be glad to discuss with community leaders and residents themselves what they think will be a fair method of dealing with this problem. The easiest thing, of course, will be to pass legislation that if there are more than three or four or X number of complaints against a particular family, the flat can be repossessed. But I do not think we should resort to such a simple administrative solution at this stage. We are always open to discussing with community organizations as to what more can be done in this respect.

PROGRESS REPORT ON THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE MRT SYSTEM
(Statement by the Minister for Communications and Information)

11.30 am

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, I would like to give Members of the House a progress report on the construction of the MRT. Barring unforeseen circumstances, the MRT will be completed ahead of original schedule and within budget. Nine months from now, just in time for Christmas, the first MRT train will begin its public service. Land transport in Singapore will take a quantum leap forward. We will join the many cities in the developed world with a mass rapid transit system that will provide fast, convenient and comfortable travel.

Construction so far

    The first pile was driven into the ground in October 1983, barely 3 1/2 years ago. Today, construction of the MRT system is progressing well. The 20 stations in Phase 1 and Phase 1A, that is, the section stretching from Yio Chu Kang all the way to Clementi, has been wholly completed structurally, as far as the 20 stations are concerned. The tunnels and the viaducts along this route have also been completed. The laying of track is about three-quarters completed and the work on Phase 2 stations, all the way to Yishun, Bukit Panjang, Lakeside, Marina Bay and Pasir Ris, these are all well in hand.

    So far seven trains have been delivered. More are undergoing testing and a total of 25 trains will be delivered by the end of the year for the first operation of the MRT trains.

Operating dates

    Targetted operating dates for the MRT system are as follows:

    Yio Chu Kang to Toa Payoh - early December 1987.

    From Toa Payoh to Outram Park - end December 1987.

Column: 248



    Outram Park on to Clementi - April 1988.

    And the various Phase 2 routes to Yishun, Bukit Panjang, Lakeside, Marina Bay and Pasir Panjang, all to be completed by June 1990.

Privatization

    Sir, last year in June, in line with our overall privatization programme, the Government decided to privatize the operation of the MRT system. The objective is to ensure that the MRT will be run efficiently and that they will be able to meet and be more responsive to the changing needs of the travelling public. To enable as many Singaporeans as possible to participate in the ownership of the MRT system, funds in the CPF will be allowed to be used for the purchase of the shares in the MRT company when it is floated. This will be similar to the SBS case.

    In September last year the Singapore International Merchant Bankers' Ltd. (SIMBL) was appointed consultant to advise on the privatization exercise of the MRT system. At the moment the consultants are about half-way through their studies. Preliminary studies by the merchant banker consultants have confirmed earlier findings that the operation of the MRT will be economically viable. The new company is expected to be called the Singapore MRT Ltd. (SMRT for short). Detailed studies are currently underway looking into all aspects of the operations of the system by the new company, including the three major areas of legislation, financial operations and flotation.

MRT - Bus integration

    Next, I come to the MRT bus integration. Sir, the next nine months are going to be intensive and trying times for all concerned with land transportation as we seek to bring the MRT in, phase it in gradually and smoothly with the rest of our land transport network. When Phase 1 and Phase 1A of the system are completely operational by April 1988, it is expected that the trains will carry about one-eighth of all public transport passenger

Column: 249

trips. Two years later, by 1990, when Phase 2 is brought in, the MRT trains will carry about a quarter of all public transport passenger trips. If the bus system remains unchanged, then total public transport operating cost must go up because we are adding operating cost of the MRT trains on to the existing bus networks. The whole process of the budget presentation is like preparing a patient who is about to go for a surgical operation. He isusually first given a jab of sedatives which will bring about a sense of euphoria and well-being over his whole body and very soon his anxieties and fears of pain will disappear.

    It is the same with this budget. Witness the increase in University students' tuition fees and the hospital prescription fees. But I must make it clear that I am not objecting to these increases. In the case of tuition fees, firstly, I think it is a good socialist principle - although we might have already forgotten about the meaning of that word now - that a privileged few should not be heavily subsidized at the expense of a large number of less privileged people, no matter how talented that group of people are. Secondly, the problem uppermost in the minds of most parents regarding their children's tertiary education is how to get a place in the University and tuition fee is always the secondary consideration. I am happy to see that the Government is considerate enough to allocate $100 million as study loans to the needy students. My only regret is that the Government should be so hard-headed and business-like in pegging the interest rate at prime rate. I think the right thing to do is to peg it at whatever rate the Government borrows from the CPF. I do not know at what rate the CPF is lending its money to the Government, but I presume it is much less than the banks. My argument for this is that prime rate can fluctuate according to the demand for capital. If everyone is crazy again to speculate in shares, gold, properties, or what-have-you, the rate can go rocket-high. We

Column: 302

are only lucky that it has reached an all-time low of 5(r)% this year. But a prime rate of 11% or 12% is not unheard of, for instance, in 1984 and 1985.

    A large loan coupled with continous high prime rate for several years may cause the future graduate to end up with having greater liabilities than his assets, in which case he may not be eligible to sign the declaration of non-indebtedness as required by the Government Manual when he joins the Government service. But I presume the bureaucrats in the Ministry of Finance are farsighted enough to foresee this eventuality and amend the Manual long before it becomes necessary.

    Since the Government is in this generous and magnanimous mood, may I venture to suggest that this $100 million loan facility be also extended to students who study in approved and recognized universities overseas. This makes good economic sense as, firstly, students studying overseas can benefit from other people's subsidies. Secondly, the fact that they are studying overseas releases more valuable places in our University for other deserving students. And thirdly, with more students studying overseas, we will have wider cross-fertilization of knowledge and greater challenges among our student population.

    As regards the increase in prescription fees, the important thing is that the drug prescribed should be good enough to cure us. If, for instance, I had cancer and if there is a drug that can cure it, I would be happy to pawn my last shirt to get it. Now that we are promised that better and proprietary drugs would be used, I think the small increase is well worth it. However, I am afraid that the trend of modern medicine is such that it will probably cause more to find out what is wrong with us than what to do with us. I suppose they call it the "science of diagnosis". I suppose that is what you call progress. I remember when I was in London and once when I had a little fever and had to go to see a doctor, I was sent round to the various laboratories all over Harley Street to have blood tests, X-rays, etc, the bills of which went up to almost 100. After a few days of rushing around in Harley Street, I went back to see the doctor again and I was given a pre-

Column: 303

scription chit and told to take two tablets prescribed therein, twice a day, and to go back to see him a week later. Meanwhile, I was charged another 25 for the doctor's consultation fee. Later, I found out that the tablet was actually a kind of analgesic though of a different brand name but was similar to Panadol, which I could have bought for 50 pence at the ordinary chemist's shop. But that was not the end of the story. Unlike doctors in Singapore, those in London do not give you medicine after they have seen you. They only give you a prescription chit and you have to run round to the nearest chemist or pharmacy to buy your medicine. In my case, since the medicine was sold on a prescription basis, the pharmacist charged me 2 for counting out the number of tablets prescribed. I suppose that is called "professional service rendered" and another 50 pence for the tablets. That is what happens in an advanced and developed country. I hope such things do not happen in Singapore. But who knows?

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, since the Minister was rather vague about the prospect of the economy and has not told us in his speech what is in store for us in the coming year, whether it is going to be a good one or a bad one, the ordinary people will have to resort to their usual horoscopic skill to tell their fortunes and the prospects for their business. Usually it is to find out what animal is in reign during that year. You must not laugh and you must not under-estimate them. More than 3,000 years of experience and knowledge have been distilled and compressed into a great proverb book called Tung Su, the Chinese Almanac. Sometimes their predictions are more accurate than PhD economists and social scientists. Remember 1985? We were then imbued with a sense of euphoria and the planners were telling us that the fun society had finally arrived and we were in for some golden harvest. The then Finance Minister was painting a rosy picture of what good things were about to come. Then some tiresome people warned that we had better watch out because the Tiger year was approaching. And sure enough, bang. In 1986, we met with the year of reckoning and we went down the slippery slope from which we have still not recovered.

Column: 304



    For this year, the Rabbit year, the optimists of the Tung Su are saying that it is going to be a good one because according to them, the rabbit is an active animal and it breeds prolifically, something which may cheer the First Deputy Prime Minister. It foretells a year of active business and increasing profits. However, on the other side of the coin, are the pessimists. Like the professional economist, these amateur soothsayers also have two schools, one optimistic and the other pessimistic. The pessimists refer us to the Chinese story about a clever rabbit having three hideouts. So does it mean that this is a year of reckoning for dishonest contractors and crooked businessmen and forewarn that they had better quickly prepare three hideouts, one in Bangkok, one in Macau and another one in Taiwan where our laws cannot get at them? Whether it is so, I do not know and I could not care less because I am not a rabbit, I am not clever, and I do not need a hideout.

    But I am more interested in that part of the story about the rabbit being a fast breeder and hope that this will lend some help to the First Deputy Prime Minister's efforts to get the nation moving again in the matter of producing babies. I really do not know what has happened to our people. After so many years of glorious achievements, we are finally caught out to be low in productivity, not only in factories but also in bedrooms. I fully understand the new population policy and I support it. But unfortunately for me, the support can only be a verbal rather than a biological one.

    However, I am not happy with the way it is being promoted. Again, we are falling into the trap of too much regulating. We must remember that we are living in a society of human beings and we must treat it as such. In a matter like this, we can only give advice and not dish out regulations. It revolts against human nature to be told how many babies he or she can or cannot have. Anyone who has any self-respect would be unhappy to be told that he or she has a quota of not two, not four, but three babies to be filled. In the field of trade, we have been vehemently against the quota system, against GSP graduation and so on. And yet when it comes to

Column: 305

producing babies we have a quota system. In the matter of the size of the family, I am in favour of letting people have their own initiative and decide on how many babies they should have.

    I am not a great admirer of Confucius. But at least in this matter about promoting a cause among the people, I agree with what he said in one of his quotations. He said, Min ke shi you zhi bu ke shi zhi zhi . There are a lot of controversies and interpretations about this quotation. And my own interpretation is this. If the people are intelligent and they understand your policy, you should let them have a free hand and take their own initiative. If they are not, you should educate them and make them understand. They will then respond more positively to what we want them to do.

    The First Deputy Prime Minister himself has said that once a departing diplomat had told him that Singaporeans lacked initiatives. They have to be told by the Government what to do about everything. That must be one of the shortcomings of our people as seen through other's eyes. I believe it also to be true and we must try to rectify it. And yet in this very personal matter about babies, the First Deputy Prime Minister is not letting the people have any initiative at all. He has to tell them how to produce and how many to produce. If we spoonfeed them at every step, how can we expect them to grow up and become an intelligent people? I am sure if we explain to them fully the dilemma we are in and the problems we are going to face, they will support the Government wholeheartedly and come out with more ingenious ideas and solutions of their own.

    I myself was very depressed when I saw the graphic about the man holding a tongkat getting bigger and bigger, meaning people above 60 getting more and more until the year 2020 when the figure becomes largest. There is little consolation to me that I am not in that group of tongkat holders yet.

    But the aging of the population is already felt in my own constituency. In the

Column: 306

past when we held baby shows or dance parties in the community centre, there was great response. Now I do not remember having any baby shows there for the last 10 years. And the activities that attract the greatest response were those meant for senior citizens. What are we going to do with so many old people? They are unproductive, fragile, grumpy and needing so many young people to support them. I understand that in the Turf Club, when a horse becomes lame or when its useful life is over, it is shot and then its carcass is fed to the animals in the Mandai Zoo. They call it humane destruction. But it would be inconceivable and we cannot do this in a human society. Or can we? I am not so sure. I cannot see what is going to come in the next 10 years, let alone in the year 2020. What was considered inconceivable in 1970 has become conceivable today, and that is only a lapse of 15 or 16 years. So what is considered inconceivable today could well be conceivable in, say, 20 or 30 years later, is it not? Fortunately or unfortunately, I would not be there to see it.

    I do not know how the magic figure of three has been produced. We were told that it was a result of statistics, charts, projections and so on. But as I have said earlier in 1985 about charts and projections, they can lead us up the rosy path but they can also plunge us into great abyss. I am not a great believer in statistics and charts. But if we must have figures to make our speeches sound more authoritative and irrefutable, then I shall do so by quoting from the latest issue of the Monthly Digest of Statistics in order to soothe the nerves of our panic-stricken Ministers. The First Deputy Prime Minister has conveniently chosen the 1986 figure to show that there is a shortfall of 14,000 to 15,000 babies. Of course, it is true that in 1986 we had 39,400 babies as against 42,484 babies in 1985. And there is a net loss of 3,084 babies, if my arithmetic is right. But does he know or has his analyst taken into consideration the fact that 1986 was a Tiger year and what implications this must have in a population which is predominantly Chinese? If we look at the figures of live births year by year, we will see that from 1982 we have been having an average of 41,000 babies every year. In fact, from 1976 onwards, the figures have

Column: 307

been increasing every year. Why is it that in all those years nobody sounded any alarm? Why has nobody tried to find out how we came to be short of 3,000 in 1986? To me, the explanation is simple and the figures are all there in that book for everyone to see. The shortfall, in fact, came from the Chinese section of the population. While the other races maintained more or less the same number of babies in 1985 and 1986, the Chinese had 29,355 babies in 1985 as against 26,108 babies in 1986, a net loss of 3,247 to be exact. Why did the Chinese produce less in 1986? You must ask the politicians and not the statisticians because the Chinese believe that although Tiger boys are good material for soldiers Tiger girls are definitely out. They believe that Tiger girls are difficult to handle and to live with. In fact, I have friends who are Tiger girls and are married to husbands of the Bull years, and they actually refrain from eating beef because they believe that Tiger girls who eat beef may bring harm to their Bull husbands. So is there anything worse than a Tiger girl who may eventually become a graduate? It has already been drummed into their ears day in and day out that a graduate girl is so difficult to get rid of, I mean in the matrimony way. So they are not taking any chances at all.

    If you look down the column of births for the Chinese and compare the monthly breakdown figures, it will become more interesting and revealing. In January 1986 the figure was an all-time high of 2,808 babies. But in the next month, February 1986, the beginning of the Tiger year, the figure plunged to an all-time low of 1,808, exactly 1,000 babies less. Do you call it coincidence or good planning? If you look at the number of marriages registered by the Chinese for the years 1985 and 1986, you will also see the same pattern. Less Chinese were prepared to get married in 1986. The figures are 16,747 in 1985 and 13,824 in 1986, about 3,000 less couples. So what does all this prove? It proves that no doubt 1986 was a bad year but it was also an exceptional one. But all is not lost. When it comes to the more auspicious years, such as the Dragon year or like this year, the Rabbit year, we may even have a baby boom and all our worries will be over.

Column: 308



    In the last few days I have been thinking very hard over ways and means to help the First Deputy Prime Minister out of the population dilemma. My thoughts first directed me to the baby boom years of 1954-1958. I wanted to find out why we had a baby boom then, and not now. I thought naively that if we could re-enact some of the conditions prevailing in those days, then we might be able to induce at least a mini-boom, if not a real one, and that might help. However, after some reflection I decided that it was a non-starter. Because not only can we not push the clock back, but do we want the conditions prevailing in those depressed and tragic years to come back to us?

    First of all, we must compare what we did have or did not have in the 1950s to what we do have or do not have now. For a start, we did not have television in the 1950s, which is a plus point as far as producing babies is concerned. This condition cannot be re-enacted now because the whole population is already addicted to television, and what is more, we also have the videotape machine which can be played right after midnight, which makes things worse. Then in the 1950s there were riots, strikes and general instability. And in those circumstances people tended to stay at home at night. There is no prize for guessing what people would do when they stay at home at night without television to watch. But do we want those conditions to come back to us? Then there was massive unemployment. Thousands of young men and women were wandering about the streets aimlessly and when boys and girls without anything better to do met, you again can easily guess what would happen. We did not need any SDU then. The matchmaker then has almost become an extinct species.

    And what is it that we have now that we did not have in the 1950s? We now have electronic factories and garment factories in which large numbers of young girls are engaged and enclosed for at least eight hours a day without any chance of meeting the boys. What is more, there is also the problem of the third shift. When they get home, they are usually too tired to go out to meet the boys. Also we now have army camps which we did not have in the

Column: 309

1950s, and they cordon off large numbers of young boys without giving them any opportunity of meeting the girls. They can go home in the weekends but marriage can hardly be struck within that short period. Cupids do not work so fast. Girls can work third shifts but cupids don't. They cannot aim their arrows so fast. So what are we going to do about it? Dismantle the factories and the army camps? We might as well dismantle ourselves.

    This led me to think of the other alternative. According to the First Deputy Prime Minister there are nearly 20,000 marriageable and biologically productive women who are not married. If we can make them produce just one baby each, then all our talk about shortfalls and crises will be over. But the problem is: why are they not married? The finger is always pointed at us, the male chauvinist pig. But I think there are always two sides to a coin. It is true that some men may be reluctant to marry some women whose academic qualification is higher than theirs. But the women themselves too are choosy and they have some sort of complex. While an ordinary man may have no hesitation in marrying a woman whose academic qualification is lower than his, a woman often refuses to marry a man whose qualification is lower than hers. I once asked a Secondary 4 girl whether she would take a boy who has not completed his Secondary 4 education to be her husband, and she said, "Very definitely no." I also asked an A-level girl whether she would take a Secondary 4 boy to be her husband, and she said, "Not really." But when I came to an older and unmarried graduate girl, I dared not pose the question because I was afraid that she might misunderstand me and think that I was trying to propose to her. But whether or not I posed the question, I suppose the answer would still be the same as the other girls. That is why I think the SDU is doing the wrong thing. They thought that if they brought the graduate boys and the graduate girls together, they will somehow hit it and that they will be married happily ever after. But judging on the fact that more girls are getting into the University than boys every year, they are really fighting a losing bat-

Column: 310

tle. It is like trying to fill a tub with water when it has a hole at the bottom. While we must try to remove the fear of the boys marrying upwards, we must also try to remove the girls' inhibitions about marrying downwards. If a graduate boy marrying a Secondary 4 girl can produce a brilliant baby, there is no reason why a graduate girl marrying a Secondary 4 boy cannot have the same result.

    I have a suggestion as to how to get these 20,000 unmarried but marriageable women on the baby-producing track. The suggestion may sound unorthodox but it is not unthinkable and neither is it unmentionable. In fact, it has been mentioned by no less a personality than the Prime Minister himself. It is called single-parenthood. What is single-parenthood? I am afraid many of our people cannot grasp the idea because it is a completely new life-style and new phenomenon from the West. A sweet young girl of a reporter from the Lianhe Zaobao, when reporting the Prime Minister's speech, explained to her readers in this way: Single-parenthood means that if an unmarried woman wishes to remain single she can do so, and in order to avoid the loneliness of old age she can adopt other people's child. I was laughing my head off with such naive and innocent interpretation. But I do not blame her. The trouble with the Chinese language is that it has no neuter noun as "parent". It has to join the characters "fu" meaning father and the character "mu" meaning mother to form the word "fu-mu" and use it to equate the English word "parent". Therefore, they have trouble in translating the word parenthood with only one sex, and it becomes rather difficult for them to conceive and understand parenthood with only a father or a mother. However, single-parenthood in the Western context means divorced men or women keeping and bringing up their children separately. It also means unmarried mothers, who cannot decide who their babies' fathers are, bringing up their babies instead of aborting them. It also means unmarried women conceived babies from men who are other women's husbands and, instead of aborting their babies, they bring them up under their maiden name. But these are not the kind of single-parenthood I have in mind. To

Column: 311

promote them would mean encouraging promiscuity and extra-marital affairs among the people and I am against it. I hope the TV will show it tonight because my wife will be watching it. However, extra-marital affairs are nothing new in oriental societies and even Confucius himself, someone whose behaviour we are emulating and whose teachings we are spreading, had been found to be involved in one. At some appropriate occasion I will produce documentary evidence and quotations found in ancient Chinese books to prove it. But right now, let us return to our procreation budget.

    My idea of single-parenthood is different. There now exists techniques which can cause the woman to conceive without so much as a touch from a man. Do you know what is it called? It is called artificial insemination. It is very safe, very convenient and can be easily administered. Furthermore, it can solve problems for women who have complexes. For instance, there are women who are born man-haters and there are also those who harbour great contempt for men, and this technique will enable them to have babies without getting near a man. To this end, I suggest that a sperm bank be set up by the Ministry of Health and unmarried women of the category mentioned above should be encouraged to apply for the service, free of charge, of course, and officials should not ask too many questions. To make the scheme a success, the Ministry of Finance should consider giving another incentive, say, $10,000, to those women who are bold enough to take that first step. And to ensure that we should have good quality and brilliant babies, we should insist that only males who are PhDs or First-Class Honours graduates may be invited to be donors.

    Our immediate problem with this scheme is that the Vatican may view us with disgust and despair but we are in unusual times and so unusual measures have to be adopted. Anyway, we have been doing a lot of things. For instance, abortion, which they view with contempt. So one more misdeed will not take us any further away from heaven. However, our long-term problem will be how to legitimize these babies. First of all, the SDU

Column: 312

should be expanded to cater for counselling of parents in this category. Then we should help by changing or amending some of the laws. For instance, the Registrar of Births and Deaths should allow the baby to be registered in the mother's family name and not insist that the column giving the father's particulars be filled. Then the Women's Charter may have to be reviewed. But since we do not have so much time, may I be allowed to stop here.

     Dr Aline K. Wong (Changkat): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, may I be allowed to join in the debate on the procreation incentives in the Budget statement. I would not have time, I think, to cover the other aspects of the Budget statement.

    The population debate has been going on for more than three years now. It is very difficult for me to understand why, after so much data have been released, statistics analysed, talks and discussions held, some Members of this House still do not grasp the essence of the matter. Population problem is a very serious matter. We appreciate the jokes. We appreciate the humour. But I believe that we really should come down to substantive arguments and criticisms, if any, of the measures proposed by the Government before we end this debate on the Budget statement.

    As a social scientist, I am satisfied that the Government has taken very serious consideration of the whole question and has utilized the best manpower we have - demographers and social scientists - in analysing the causes and proposing the right measures. May I congratulate the Government for having come up with a series of incentives which indeed address the balance that we have to maintain between the requirements for population quantity and quality. In the past, the issue of quantity versus quality understandably has upset some people because the undertones of such requirements touch on issues of equality and basic rights of individuals to decide on matters as personal as child-bearing.

    However, we should note that governments around the world have used policy intervention in population matters. Witness their selective immigration policies, the family planning policies as well as their

Column: 313

policies on abortion. For us, to have such a small population that we have now and will have, considerations for quality are equally important as considerations for quantity. We do not live in an ideal world and if we are convinced that the new population policy is good for the long-term future of the country, I believe a trade-off has to be made. Something has to be sacrificed. So it is not a matter of whether or not we should have the new population measures but a matter of how best to devise a set of measures that are effective while minimizing some of the undesirable consequences such as an accentuation of social inequality or, more importantly, the degree of perceived inequality. It is here that I feel that the present set of incentives has come short on the question of equity.

    The new set of tax incentives, Sir, gives a big advantage to the higher income groups. The $20,000 special tax rebate together with a special rebate of 15% on the wife's earned income, on top of the enhanced child relief which can by itself run up to $10,000 already in terms of offsetting, all these will result in some families paying no income tax for five years at all. Does this sound right? The highest income groups, perhaps those earning $6,000 household income per month, will pay some tax but these families will be able to absorb the entire tax rebate within five years. In other words, they stand to gain the most. Even if we accept that the higher income groups are better able to provide a conducive home environment and such like to bring up children and therefore they should be encouraged to have more, I feel such kind of disparity in treatment is going to create social resentment. How could the general population accept this? How could this measure go down well with them?

    With effect from 1st January 1988, delivery and hospital expenses for the fourth child can be offset against the parent's earned income for tax purposes up to a maximum of $3,000. What we are doing is not only to allow some people to pay no income tax at all for five years but also to have the babies in Class A wards, in luxury. Surely, the Finance Minister could

Column: 314

have thought about this and could have limited the amount of offsetting only up to what the average Singaporean would be paying for hospital and delivery charges, ie, in the Class B1 and Class B2 wards only. I think this would go down much better with the population.

    In talking about the overall effectiveness of these measures, even if the higher income families are now prompted to have a third child, the number of additional births would not be large enough to make a difference to the population size. Whereas if you compare the small size of this high income group with the large number of families where women have three 'O' levels and above, you would find this latter group would make more difference to the population size. For this large group, economic considerations in the past were important considerations for not having more children. Thus, the tax incentives are more likely to help them to decide on having a third child. So the number of additional births resulting from such decisions is likely to be much larger because of the larger base to be begin with.

    Sir, we must be concerned with the question of numbers. It is not only because last year happened to be the year of the Tiger that the number of births among certain population groups has gone down. Since 1982 we have been short of the number of live births required to place the population back to replacement level by 14,000 to 15,000. The trend has been well established and has been identified. Numbers matter. As for quality, I am of the opinion that parents with a relatively good level of education, such as those who have already got three 'O' levels and above, also place great importance on the children's education. This, on both counts of quantity and quality, the effectiveness of the tax incentives is more likely to be felt among this group and not among those in the higher income groups.

    If I could provoke the Finance Minister a little, I'd like to ask him how many years is he prepared to wait for the special tax rebate to take effect, and if after that number of years the tax rebate is not seen to be effective in raising the number of additional births among the higher income

Column: 315

groups, will he consider withdrawing it so that there will be a better balance in terms of fairness?

    There is another point. Why is it that 1st January 1987 is set as the beginning date, whereas for every other financial measure, it is always on the day that the Budget is announced that things take effect. Could the Finance Minister please explain the rationale for backdating the incentives to take effect from 1st January of this year?

    The effectiveness of the population measures must be viewed within the entire package of incentives and not just the fiscal measures. If the Finance Minister will bear with me and since I see the Acting Minister for Health is also here, I would like to go over the other incentives. Let me first state that in the past, the primary school priority registration scheme was the most important deterrent to higher order births because of the value our population places on the education of children. By removing the disincentive against the third child in the priority registration of primary school children, we are doing the right thing. In other words, it will be effective on parents who place so much emphasis on the education of their children.

    By comparison, giving housing priority to families with three children who are now living in 3-room flats and who may require additional space, this incentive may not be as effective as we would expect it to be. Here, we should also sound a word of caution. The families, even given this incentive, should not rush into making a move. They should carefully consider the possibility of a drop in family income due to retrenchment. The recession should have taught us a lesson. By giving them housing priority, the Government cannot guarantee their continuing affordability. And still, there is the questionable assumption that living space is an important consideration for family size decisions. If it is, then how does one explain the fact that that those who live in 5-room flats already do not have a bigger family size than the rest? And if this incentive is actually meant to also work as a disincentive to discourage those who live in the 1- and 2-room flats from having many children, then why did not space constraint work on these families to limit

Column: 316

family size in the past? So it is a questionable assumption to what extent is living space an effective influence on family size?

    Let me come quickly to the major thrust of the non-fiscal measures - the provisions to enable working women to have more children. For many years, women have been asking for more subsidized child-care centres, part-time and flexi-time work, extended no-pay leave for child care and full-pay unrecorded leave for taking care of sick children. They have repeatedly called for these provisions because, without them, it is well-nigh impossible to hold a job, do well in it and at the same time pay enough attention to one or two children, let alone have more. Thus, the full-scale response of the Government to their demands and requests is most welcome news to women indeed. We note, however, that quite a lot depends on the cooperation of the employers in matters such as providing part-time work, flexi-time arrangements, granting of extended no-pay leave, etc.

    While it is only fair that the employers should indeed have the right to decide based on exigencies of service, the question is how can women be sure that employers would indeed take a sympathetic view in spite of the assurances given by the Acting Minister for Health and various other Ministers. Also, will the private sector really follow the example set by the Civil Service? Already some women are becoming apprehensive that there may be a backlash effect in terms of a reduction in the demand for female employees, particularly in the private sector. So I believe, Sir, that the Government must demonstrate its will to implement these schemes with success, to demonstrate its sincerity in helping women to combine work and having a family and, by example, encourage the private sector to follow because if it does not, then the private sector would stand to lose in terms of not finding enough women to work in the companies and firms.

    Finally, even though compulsory counselling is introduced for abortees, the question of abortion is not yet resolved. But each year we know there are many thousands of babies lost through abortion.

Column: 317

I think, Sir, this question of abortion must be faced, the sooner the better.

    A final final word on matchmaking. All of us must remember that as much as half of the population problem arises out of the high proportion of unmarried persons in the population. Ever since the matchmaking activities have been extended to those with "0" level qualifications, much social stigma attached to those activities has already been removed. But matchmaking is only part of the solution. The larger solution really lies in changing people's attitudes towards marital choice and the marriage relationship itself. It is most heartening to hear from the Acting Minister for Health himself that the right emphasis must be put back on people's motivations for having children. People must value children for themselves. Children should be seen as bringing warmth and happiness to the family rather than as a product of the parents' calculation of financial or economic considerations.
